questionCopy: Do you have a Registered Nurse (RN) on staff?
Do you have an RN on call?
Do you have a Licensed Practial Nurse (LPN) on staff?
Is either an RN or an LPN on staff 24 hours a day, 7 days a week?
What is the ratio of Certified Nursing Assistants (CNA) to residents?
Do you have a Medical Director?
Do you have a doctor that comes to your community?
How often?
Does the doctor take all tyoes of insurances?
Do you have a shower schedule?
How many days a week do the residents receive showers?
If they want more showers, is there a charge for that?
Does someone stay in the room while the resident is taking a shower?
Do you provide assistance with dressing and personal care?
Is there an extra charge for that?
How much personal care does a resident receive in an ALF?
Do you provide incontinence care?
is there an extra charge for that?
What is your policy concerning a bedside commode?
Do you provide assistance in transporting a resident to the dining room or activity room if needed?
Is there an extra charge for that?
Do you check on the residents during the night?
Can residents keep their own doctors?
Do you provide transportation to that doctor?
Is there an extra charge for that?
Do you make doctor appointments for the residents?
Do you have an emergency response system?
How does it work?
Do you have a pull cord in the bathroom or the bedroom, or do the residents wear a pendant?
Do you charge for Level of Care?
What are the costs for each Level of Care?
What personal care items are included in the rate?
What is your policy regarding medication supplies?
Can residents get their medication from the VA clinic or another entity and bring it to the ALF?
Who supplies resident medications?
How is the medication billed?
Who dispenses the medication?
Is your staff trained to dispense medication?
Is your staff supervised by a nurse while they are dispensing medications?
Can residents take their own medication?
What is your policy on self-medication?
Do you have adjustable beds?
Who supplies incontient supplies?
Who pays for incontinent supplies?
Do you have a Home Health Agency in house?
Can I have their business card?
Can residents use the Home Health Agency in the event they need extra services?
Do you have a Physical Therapy Agency in your facility?
What insurances do they accept?
Is the Physical Therapy Agency part of your staff?
If not, can I have their busiess card?
Does a Podiatrist visit your community on a regular basis?
How often?
What insurance does he accept?
Do you accept any feeding tubes?
If residents can manage their own feeding tubes, can they be admitted to your community?
Can you take a person with a colostomy?
Do you provide nebulizer treatments?
Can you admit a person who requires oxygen?
Can a resident live in your ALF with a catheter?
Can a resident who requires thickened liquids reside in your community?
Does your staff assist residents who require thickened liquids?
What is your policy on the use of thickened liquids?
What is your policy on wound care?
Can you provide IV therapy?
Can a resident use an electric wheelchair in your community?
When is a resident no longer able to live in your community?
How long can a resident be bedridden and still remain in your commuity?
Does your community allow private aides to assist residents if needed?
Can a family member or friend sleep over in a resident's room?
Is there a charge for that?
Can a resident be on Hospice care and still reside in your community?
Can a person with Dementia or Alzheimer's live in your community?
If so, is there a seperate area of the community where they reside?
Is your staff trained to handle peopel with Dementia or Alzheimer's?
Is the resident's privacy respected?
Does your staff knock on the door before entering the room?
Are the residents treated with respect and dignity?
Can a resident be transferred with assistance by more than one person?
Can a resident with a communicable disease be admitted?
